report_header.title: Weekly Training Report
report_header.scope: Detailed analysis of the last 7 days of training activity
report_header.intended_use: Day-to-day coaching decisions, intensity balance, short-term fatigue and recovery management

ACWR.name: ACWR
ACWR.interpretation: EWMA Acute:Chronic Load Ratio — compares 7-day vs 28-day weighted loads. 0.8–1.3 = productive training, <0.8 = recovery or detraining, >1.5 = overload/injury risk.
ACWR.coaching_implication: If ACWR > 1.5, reduce intensity and focus on recovery to avoid overload. If ACWR < 0.8, gradually increase training load with controlled progression to build endurance.

Monotony.name: Monotony
Monotony.interpretation: 1–2 shows healthy variation; >2.5 means repetitive stress pattern.
Monotony.coaching_implication: If Monotony > 2.5, introduce more variation in training or implement a deload week to reduce repetitive stress.

Strain.name: Strain
Strain.interpretation: Product of load × monotony; >3500 signals potential overreach.
Strain.coaching_implication: If Strain > 3000, monitor for signs of overreach and consider more rest or deloading. If Strain > 3500, consider reducing volume or intensity temporarily.

FatigueTrend.name: FatigueTrend
FatigueTrend.interpretation: FatigueTrend is calculated as the percentage change between the 7-day and 28-day moving averages. A 0% change indicates balance, while a positive percentage change indicates accumulating fatigue, and a negative percentage change indicates recovery.
FatigueTrend.coaching_implication: If FatigueTrend is negative (e.g., below -0.2), this indicates a recovering state. Continue with controlled training load and focus on recovery to ensure sustained progress. Avoid aggressive increases in load.

ZQI.name: ZQI
ZQI.interpretation: Zone Quality Index (%) 5-15 high-intensity time is normal <3% too easy, >20% too intense or erratic pacing.
ZQI.coaching_implication: If ZQI > 20%, review pacing strategy; excessive high-intensity time could indicate erratic pacing or overtraining. Aim for 5-15% ZQI for balanced training.

FatOxEfficiency.name: FatOxEfficiency
FatOxEfficiency.interpretation: 0.4–0.8 means balanced fat oxidation; lower = carb dependence.
FatOxEfficiency.coaching_implication: If FatOxEfficiency is low (<0.6), focus on improving aerobic base with longer, low-intensity efforts.

PolarisationIndex.name: PolarisationIndex
PolarisationIndex.interpretation: Normalized time-in-zone index (0–1) showing total proportion of training spent in low and moderate intensities (Z1+Z2). ≥0.75 indicates strong aerobic bias, 0.6–0.74 = mixed distribution, <0.6 = threshold dominance.
PolarisationIndex.coaching_implication: If PolarisationIndex <0.60, training load is too threshold-heavy. Rebalance toward greater Z1 endurance and reduced Z2 time. Target ≥0.75 for efficient aerobic adaptation and recovery balance.

FOxI.name: FOxI
FOxI.interpretation: FatOx index %; higher values mean more efficient aerobic base.
FOxI.coaching_implication: If FOxI is increasing, continue to prioritize low-intensity work to enhance fat metabolism. If it decreases, consider increasing your Zone 2 training duration.

CUR.name: CUR
CUR.interpretation: Carbohydrate Utilisation Ratio; 30-80 balanced metabolic use.
CUR.coaching_implication: If CUR is outside the green zone (30-70), adjust carbohydrate intake and fueling strategy to ensure balanced metabolic use during long sessions.

GR.name: GR
GR.interpretation: Glucose Ratio; >2 indicates excess glycolytic bias.
GR.coaching_implication: If GR exceeds 2.0, focus on reducing glycolytic intensity and increase aerobic work. Ensure sufficient recovery to avoid over-reliance on carbs.

MES.name: MES
MES.interpretation: Metabolic Efficiency Score; >20 is good endurance economy.
MES.coaching_implication: If MES is below 20, work on improving metabolic efficiency by increasing endurance training with a focus on aerobic base and fat metabolism.

RecoveryIndex.name: RecoveryIndex
RecoveryIndex.coaching_implication: If RecoveryIndex is low (<0.7), ensure adequate rest and recovery, and avoid heavy training loads.

StressTolerance.name: StressTolerance
StressTolerance.coaching_implication: If StressTolerance is high (>8), reduce overall load and increase recovery time. If it's low (<2), ensure proper training load progression.

Polarisation.name: Polarisation
Polarisation.interpretation: Seiler Polarisation Ratio showing the balance of low- and high-intensity work relative to moderate-intensity (Z2) training. ≥1.0 indicates a well-polarised (80/20) structure; 0.7–0.99 = mixed; <0.7 = threshold-heavy. Displayed in reports as a percentage (e.g., 0.78 → 78%).
Polarisation.coaching_implication: If Polarisation <0.7, increase low-intensity (Z1) aerobic volume and distinct high-intensity (Z3) sessions to achieve ≥1.0. Maintain ≥1.0 for a balanced 80/20 distribution. Reported as a percentage (e.g., 0.78 → 78%).

events.name: Zwift - Group Workout: BaseCamp Lower-Cadence Tempo with High-Cadence Surges
Zwift - Group Workout: BaseCamp Aerobic Endurance with Cadence 30-30 Intervals and Tempo

actions: ⚠ Improve Zone 2 efficiency: extend duration or adjust IF.
⚠ FatigueTrend (-13.7%) — Recovery phase detected. Maintain steady training load and prioritize recovery.
✅ Durability improving (1.00) — maintain current long-ride structure.
⚠ Load intensity too high (LIR=2.00) — reduce intensity or monitor recovery.

fatigue_trend.interpretation: FatigueTrend is calculated as the percentage change between the 7-day and 28-day moving averages. A 0% change indicates balance, while a positive percentage change indicates accumulating fatigue, and a negative percentage change indicates recovery.
fatigue_trend.coaching_implication: If FatigueTrend is negative (e.g., below -0.2), this indicates a recovering state. Continue with controlled training load and focus on recovery to ensure sustained progress. Avoid aggressive increases in load.

load_distribution.interpretation: Seiler Polarisation Ratio showing the balance of low- and high-intensity work relative to moderate-intensity (Z2) training. ≥1.0 indicates a well-polarised (80/20) structure; 0.7–0.99 = mixed; <0.7 = threshold-heavy. Displayed in reports as a percentage (e.g., 0.78 → 78%).

metabolic_drift.interpretation: Proxy derived from fat oxidation efficiency. Interpret trend direction only, not absolute magnitude.

fitness_phase.interpretation: EWMA Acute:Chronic Load Ratio — compares 7-day vs 28-day weighted loads. 0.8–1.3 = productive training, <0.8 = recovery or detraining, >1.5 = overload/injury risk.
fitness_phase.coaching_implication: If ACWR > 1.5, reduce intensity and focus on recovery to avoid overload. If ACWR < 0.8, gradually increase training load with controlled progression to build endurance.

positive.name: Polarisation
positive.interpretation: Seiler Polarisation Ratio showing the balance of low- and high-intensity work relative to moderate-intensity (Z2) training. ≥1.0 indicates a well-polarised (80/20) structure; 0.7–0.99 = mixed; <0.7 = threshold-heavy. Displayed in reports as a percentage (e.g., 0.78 → 78%).
positive.coaching_implication: If Polarisation <0.7, increase low-intensity (Z1) aerobic volume and distinct high-intensity (Z3) sessions to achieve ≥1.0. Maintain ≥1.0 for a balanced 80/20 distribution. Reported as a percentage (e.g., 0.78 → 78%).
